Austin High uses the Academy Model to group students into four academies – Academy of Classical Studies, Design & Technology, Global Studies, and Science & Innovation. In order to create identities for these academies and have them be successful through collaboration and connection, multiple planning issues and concerns need to be addressed. Interview Overview The interview was completed with Principal Amy Taylor and addressed shortcomings and time was an open-concept floor plan. Since then, the school has been subdivided into individual studios, and now these insular spaces with no natural daylight do not match the concept and goals of the academies. Student group work rooms of varying sizes are desired along with added transparency from the studios. Each of the academies needs to function for its intended goals. For instance, Science & Innovation needs to have access to collaboration and maker the District’s Educational Specifications are embedded into the pillars of learning for the academies, and the current design (studios and support spaces) does not match that learning model. Some teachers take students to the nearby Austin Public Library to use the small group rooms, and the campus would like to have a similar resource – servable, technology-rich small and medium group rooms. Looking to the future, labs/maker spaces might need to function differently. They may not be tied directly to a studio or an instructor and might function more as a checkout resource. A music production studio, like the current film production studio, is also requested. There is a huge interest in music editing due to the connection to the Austin music scene. While a complete overhaul of the interior may not be possible, the principal did stress the importance of upgrading the furniture. While the campus is large with ample daylight and courtyards for outdoor learning, it needs renovations and modernizations to meet the current Educational Specifications. The primary campus building is one story with traditional double-loaded academic corridors and fullheight exterior windows that maximize natural light in the studios. There is no transparency between most studios and corridors and no room for collaboration or breakout space outside the studios. Most of the furniture and finishes are outdated and need updates to fully support a modern and collaborative learning environment. The athletic additions are undersized, difficult to navigate and need modernization. The campus is scheduled to school year. The renovations will consist of reconfiguring some academic studios, CTE rooms, and athletic spaces to functionally support the programs at LASA. Newly accommodated programs will include dance, guitar/jazz band, wood shop, metal shop, robotics, scitech, and additional science labs. The student parking lot on the north side of the building will be reconfigured and restriped to support marching band practice. Interview Overview The interview was conducted virtually with the future users of the campus, the Liberal Arts and Science Academy. We were joined by Principal Crescenzi along with select faculty and staff. While participants generally expressed the need for more space for their growing enrollment, they agreed there are some features of the campus that should be preserved. These features include the Veterans’ Memorial at the main entrance, the future College Center and the existing courtyards that provide access to daylight, views and outdoor learning opportunities. Participants also shared their concerns about the suitability of certain programmatic spaces. Both the main gymnasium and the Performing Arts Center are undersized, and neither can support wholecampus events. The campus has no dedicated marching pad, and the interior Report Future Liberal Arts and Science Academy support spaces are undersized for their robust music program. In the CTE and Fine Arts wing, the robotics room is limited by the low ceiling height. The wrestling room needs a dedicated practice area, and the weight room could be larger. Some teachers expressed concerns about the lack of flexible collaboration spaces throughout the campus. In the future, the school hopes to include programs such as music production, anthropology, animation production, biotech lab research, fire academy, marketing/business/accounting, and sports medicine. These programs need room to grow, and participants emphasized the lack of available interior space as a significant barrier to programmatic growth. Campus representatives shared their hope to create more permanent outdoor learning spaces in the exterior courtyards. Establishing strong network connections that support digital learning will be an important consideration for future campus planning.
